content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.Consider the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to x, equals one half times the sine of, open parenthesis, the fraction pi over 2, end fraction, times x, close parenthesis, times the square root of, y plus 7, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><msqrt><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="y equals f of x " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the particular solution to the differential equation with the initial condition <math alttext="f of 1 equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is defined for all real numbers.(a) A portion of the slope field for the differential equation is given. Sketch the solution curve through the point <math alttext="with coordinates 1 comma 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>x</mi></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>x</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> is a real number.Consider the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to x, equals one half times the sine of, open parenthesis, the fraction pi over 2, end fraction, times x, close parenthesis, times the square root of, y plus 7, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><msqrt><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>. Let <math alttext="y equals f of x " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be the particular solution to the differential equation with the initial condition <math alttext="f of 1 equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. The function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is defined for all real numbers.(a) A portion of the slope field for the differential equation is given. Sketch the solution curve through the point <math alttext="with coordinates 1 comma 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Write an equation for the line tangent to the solution curve in part (a) at the point <math alttext="with coordinates 1 comma 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Use the equation to approximate <math alttext=" f of 0.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.8</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) It is known that <math alttext="f double prime of x, is greater than 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>></mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="negative 1 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is the approximation found in part (b) an overestimate or an underestimate for <math alttext=" f of 0.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.8</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

(d) Use separation of variables to find <math alttext="y equals f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the particular solution to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y with respect to x, equals one half times the sine of, open parenthesis, the fraction pi over 2, end fraction, times x, close parenthesis, times the square root of, y plus 7, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>x</mi></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><msqrt><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> with the initial condition <math alttext="f of 1 equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 4.6: Approximating Values of a Function Using Local Linearity and Linearization

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
